title: Moreland City Council withdraws plan to DNA test dog poo on footpath in Melbourne
text:
A local council has abandoned its $100,000 plan to crack down on irresponsible pet owners and DNA test dog poo left on the footpath.

Moreland City Council's Lambros Tapinos withdrew his application right before a council meeting in Melbourne on Wednesday night.

The proposal had been targeted towards residents who walked their dogs and refused to pick up their pet's poo, ABC reported.

For it to have worked, DNA would have been taken from pets when their owners brought them into the vet for microchipping.

A local council has abandoned its $100,000 plan to crack down on irresponsible pet owners and DNA test dog poo left on the footpath (stock image)

The information would then be stored on a database and cross referenced with the DNA found in the animal's faeces left on the footpath.

Though a specialist operator would've been required to carry out the test, with costs starting from an eye-watering $100,000.

The proposal drew plenty of backlash and Cr Tapinos admitted it might have not been in the public interest.

'I acknowledge that it was probably a little bit too visionary considering there wasn't an operator in Australia,' he told council.

'I acknowledge that the innovative approach of DNA is not necessarily feasible.'

Mr Tapinos had been pushing for the plan as he believed not enough pet owners were being fined for their irresponsibility.

'What we have is a local law but we have failed to fine any individual,' he said.

He looked to overseas countries like the US and UK, which had successfully implemented the system in some of its cities.

Though other councilors strongly opposed the plan for numerous reasons.

Councillor Oscar Yildiz told 3AW the proposal would've raised the fee for dog registration and the price would have been lifted to in excess of $500.

Mayor Natalie Abboud also stepped in to argue the issue was not a priority.

Councillor Tapinos will instead focus on an awareness campaign.

Daily Mail Australia contacted Moreland City Council for comment.
